prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator setup: In this setting we will observe HCO+, HCN and H13CN J=4-3, CS J=7-6 and 12CO J=3-2. For the lines we require a bandwidth of >100 km/s so as to be sensitive to any high-velocity emission from the outflow and in order that the continuum level can be identified and subtracted cleanly.
Spectral resolution: Although the expected line widths are of order 3 km/s, we need to fully resolve the lines in order to quantify the dynamics of the source. We therefore require a spectral resolution in all lines better than 0.2 km/s. In the outer envelope (>1000AU) where the line profiles are simpler but weaker we will rebin the spectra to improve the S/N.
Spectral resolution: In order to quantify the dynamics of the lines, which should be of order 3 km/s wide, we require a spectral resolution in all lines better than 0.2 km/s.
Line and Continuum Flux Densities: The peak continuum flux density (24mJy/beam) was calculated assuming that the flux detected towards the fainter component (A2) by Jorgensen et al. (2007) (2.4Jy in a 1.2x1.2" beam) is evenly distributed within the SMA beam. We ran a RATRAN model for HCN J=4-3 using the best-fit profile from Mottram et al., 2013 and assuming that the density and temperature in the inner 400AU is constant. This gives a peak flux density of 289mJy/beam and suggest we will detect lines at 3xrms out to radii of at least 5" (1200AU). These simulations are conservative so as to give a worst-case scenario and the other lines will all be as bright or brighter. Both the continuum and line flux densities are therefore lower limits.
Imaging: In order to link the kinematics of the gas in the inner envelope and disk we require overlap with current single-dish studies which can constrain the structure down to a radius ~1000 AU. Our largest spatial extent required is therefore 17", corresponding to a radius of ~2000 AU. This will require the ACA and total power observations, with two main-array configurations required due to the high spatial resolution, which was included in the simulations (see Fig 2. of the science case). From the simulations we also know that the observing time is sufficient for good UV coverage and that the elongated beam-shape recovered as a result of the high declination does not affect our ability to reach our scientific goals. However, we suggest that we will need to use configurations C34-7, C34-2 and 7m-NS to minimise shadowing. There are no extraordinary constraints on the calibration, bandpass accuracy or for scheduling.
Sensitivity: In order to trace material as it falls onto the disks in the protobinary we need to detect the line-wings of HCN J=4-3 out to radii of at least 250AU (~1"). This requires a sensitivity, based on the RATRAN models, of 10mJy. The other lines will be equally bright or brighter, giving information about larger scales. In addition, as the models almost certainly underestimate the sensitivities we will likely be able to detect even this line at larger radii. We expect to detect H13CN J=4-3 in the central region where the optical depth of H12CN may be an issue. If required, the observations of this line can be resampled to lower spatial resolution to improve the S/N.
Data Rate: This setting has a data-rate of 13.6 MB/s. All lines have been scientifically justified and the bandwidths cannot be set any smaller because we are require enough continuum either side of our lines and in some cases are expecting to see outflow emission out to +-25 km/s.

Correlator setup: In this setting we will observe HCO+ and HCN J=3-2. The addition of the continuum-model setting will enable us to not only detect the dust continuum towards the protostars but also further out, providing strong constraints to the physical structure. For the lines we require a bandwidth of >100 km/s so as to be sensitive to any high-velocity emission from the outflow and in order that the continuum level can be identified and subtracted cleanly.
Spatial resolution: In order to resolve the disks around IRAS4A1 and A2 (0.44x0.24" and 0.55x0.30'), Choi et al., 2010) we require the highest possible spatial resolution (0.16").
Spectral resolution: Although the expected line widths are of order 3 km/s, we need to fully resolve the lines in order to quantify the dynamics of the source. We therefore require a spectral resolution in all lines better than 0.2 km/s. In the outer envelope (>1000AU) where the line profiles are simpler but weaker we will rebin the spectra to improve the S/N.
Line and Continuum Flux Densities: The peak continuum flux density (17.8mJy/beam) was calculated assuming that the flux detected towards the fainter component (A2) by Jorgensen et al. (2007) (1.0Jy in a 1.2x1.2" beam) is evenly distributed within the SMA beam. We ran a RATRAN model for HCN J=3-2 using the best-fit profile from Mottram et al., 2013 and assuming that the density and temperature in the inner 400AU is constant. This gives a peak flux density of 374mJy/beam and suggest we will detect lines at 3xrms out to radii of at least 6.5" (1500AU). These simulations are conservative so as to give a worst-case scenario and the other lines will all be as bright or brighter. Both the continuum and line flux densities are therefore lower limits.
Imaging: In order to link the kinematics of the gas in the inner envelope and disk we require overlap with current single-dish studies which can constrain the structure down to a radius ~1000 AU. Our largest spatial extent required is therefore 17", corresponding to a radius of ~2000 AU. This will require the ACA and total power observations, with two main-array configurations required due to the high spatial resolution, which was included in the simulations (see Fig 2. of the science case). From the simulations we also know that the observing time is sufficient for good UV coverage and that the elongated beam-shape recovered as a result of the high declination does not affect our ability to reach our scientific goals. However, we suggest that we will need to use configurations C34-7, C34-2 and 7m-NS to minimise shadowing. There are no extraordinary constraints on the calibration, bandpass accuracy or for scheduling.
Sensitivity: In order to trace material as it falls onto the disks in the protobinary we need to detect the line-wings of the weakest line (HCN J=3-2) out to radii of at least 250AU (~1"). This requires a sensitivity, based on the RATRAN models, of 10mJy. The other lines will be equally bright or brighter, giving information about larger scales. In addition, as the models almost certainly underestimate the sensitivities we will likely be able to detect even this line at larger radii.

Correlator setup: In this setting we will observe three lines of H2CO, 13CO and C18O J=2-1 and DCO+ J=3-2. For the 13CO and C18O we require a bandwidth of >100 km/s so as to be sensitive to high-velocity emission from the outflow. In the other lines we require a bandwidth >50 km/s in order that the continuum level can be identified and subtracted cleanly.
Spatial resolution: In order to resolve the disks around IRAS4A1 and A2 (0.44x0.24" and 0.55x0.30'), Choi et al., 2010) we require the highest possible spatial resolution (0.2").
Spectral resolution: Although the expected line widths are of order 3 km/s, we need to fully resolve the lines in order to quantify the dynamics of the source. We therefore require a spectral resolution in all lines better than 0.2 km/s. In the outer envelope (>1000AU) where the line profiles are simpler but weaker we will rebin the spectra to improve the S/N.
Line and Continuum Flux Densities: The peak continuum flux density (27.8mJy/beam) was calculated assuming that the flux detected towards the fainter component (A2) by Jorgensen et al. (2007) (1.0Jy in a 1.2x1.2" beam) is evenly distributed within the SMA beam. We ran a RATRAN model for the faintest H2CO line using the best-fit profile from Mottram et al., 2013 and assuming that the density and temperature in the inner 400AU is constant. This gives a peak flux density of 58.6mJy/beam and suggest we will detect lines at 3xrms out to radii of at least 1.5" (350AU). These simulations are conservative so as to give a worst-case scenario and the other lines will all be as bright or brighter. Both the continuum and line flux densities are therefore lower limits.
Imaging: In order to link the kinematics of the gas in the inner envelope and disk we require overlap with current single-dish studies which can constrain the structure down to a radius ~1000 AU. Our largest spatial extent required is therefore 17", corresponding to a radius of ~2000 AU. This will require the ACA and total power observations, with two main-array configurations required due to the high spatial resolution, which was included in the simulations (see Fig 2. of the science case). From the simulations we also know that the observing time is sufficient for good UV coverage and that the elongated beam-shape recovered as a result of the high declination does not affect our ability to reach our scientific goals. However, we suggest that we will need to use configurations C34-7, C34-2 and 7m-NS to minimise shadowing. There are no extraordinary constraints on the calibration, bandpass accuracy or for scheduling.
Sensitivity: In order to trace material as it falls onto the disks in the protobinary we need to detect the line-wings of the weakest H2CO line (H2CO 3(2,2)-2(2,0)) out to radii of at least 250AU (~1"). This requires a sensitivity, based on the RATRAN models, of 5mJy. The other lines will be equally bright or brighter, giving information about larger scales. In addition, as the models almost certainly underestimate the sensitivities we will likely be able to detect even this line at larger radii.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The kinematics of the gas in protostars during the Class 0 phase has a long-lasting impact on the evolution of the star and its disk. The rate of mass infall and the interplay between infall and rotation control the growth of the disk and star, and influence how much angular momentum (and mass) must be removed from the system by the outflow. If the mass loading is high relative to the outflow and accretion rates then the disk can become unstable, leading to episodic accretion. However, to date few studies have been able to trace the path of material from the inner envelope on 1000AU scales down to the disk.
We propose to observe the low-mass protobinary NGC1333-IRAS4A using 3 settings. This is the perfect source to study the kinematic interplay of young multiple systems due to its very high mass infall rate and moderate binary separation. Using a combination of molecular tracers and transitions we will disentangle and constrain the temperature, density and kinematics of material in the circumbinary envelope, disks and outflow of this system. We require both the highest resolution possible (0.12-0.2") and ACA and TP observations to link the inner envelope to the smallest scales.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
